title: 20 Month Questionnaire
/COMMUNICATION/questions/0/question: Does your child imitate a two-word sentence? For example, when you say a two-word phrase, such as “Mama eat,” “Daddy play,” “Go home,” or “What’s this?” does your child say both words back to you? (Mark “yes” even if her words are difficult to understand.)
/COMMUNICATION/questions/1/question: Does your child say eight or more words in addition to “Mama” and “Dada”?
/COMMUNICATION/questions/2/question: Without your showing him, does your child point to the correct picture when you say, “Show me the kitty,” or ask, “Where is the dog?” (He needs to identify only one picture correctly.)
/COMMUNICATION/questions/3/question: If you point to a picture of a ball (kitty, cup, hat, etc.) and ask your child, “What is this?” does your child correctly name at least one picture?
/COMMUNICATION/questions/4/question: Without your giving him clues by pointing or using gestures, can your child carry out at least three of these kinds of directions? a. “Put the toy on the table.” d. “Find your coat.” b. “Close the door.” e. “Take my hand.” c. “Bring me a towel.” f. “Get your book.”
/COMMUNICATION/questions/5/question: Does your child say two or three words that represent different ideas together, such as “See dog,” “Mommy come home,” or “Kitty gone”? (Don’t count word combinations that express one idea, such as “byebye,” “all gone,” “all right,” and “What’s that?”) Please give an example of your child’s word combinations:
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/0/question: Does your child climb on an object such as a chair to reach something he wants (for example, to get a toy on a counter or to “help” you in the kitchen)?
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/1/question: Does your child walk well and seldom fall?
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/2/question: Does your child walk down stairs if you hold onto one of her hands? She may also hold onto the railing or wall. (You can look for this at a store, on a playground, or at home.)
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/3/question: When you show your child how to kick a large ball, does he try to kick the ball by moving his leg forward or by walking into it? (If your child already kicks a ball, mark “yes” for this item.)
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/4/question: Does your child run fairly well, stopping herself without bumping into things or falling?
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/5/question: Does your child walk either up or down at least two steps by himself? He may also hold onto the railing or wall.
/FINE MOTOR/questions/0/question: Does your child make a mark on the paper with the tip of a crayon (or pencil or pen) when trying to draw?
/FINE MOTOR/questions/1/question: Does your child stack three small blocks or toys on top of each other by herself? (You could also use spools of thread, small boxes, or toys that are about 1 inch in size.)
/FINE MOTOR/questions/2/question: Does your child turn the pages of a book by himself? (He may turn more than one page at a time.)
/FINE MOTOR/questions/3/question: Does your child get a spoon into her mouth right side up so that the food usually doesn’t spill?
/FINE MOTOR/questions/4/question: Does your child stack six small blocks or toys on top of each other by himself?
/FINE MOTOR/questions/5/question: Does your child use a turning motion with her hand while trying to turn doorknobs, wind up toys, twist tops, or screw lids on and off jars?
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/0/question: Without your showing him how, does your child scribble back and forth when you give him a crayon (or pencil or pen)?
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/1/question: After watching you draw a line from the top of the paper to the bottom with a crayon (or pencil or pen), does your child copy you by drawing a single line on the paper in any direction? (Mark “not yet” if your child scribbles back and forth.)
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/2/question: If you do any of the following gestures, does your child copy at least one of them? a. Open and close your mouth. c. Pull on your earlobe. b. Blink your eyes. d. Pat your cheek.
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/3/question: If you give your child a bottle, spoon, or pencil upside down, does she turn it right side up so that she can use it properly?
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/4/question: While your child watches, line up four objects like blocks or cars in a row. Does your child copy or imitate you and line up at least two blocks side by side? (You can also use spools of thread, small boxes, or other toys.)
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/5/question: If your child wants something he cannot reach, does he find a chair or box to stand on to reach it (for example, to get a toy on a counter or to “help” you in the kitchen)?
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/0/question: Does your child feed herself with a spoon, even though she may spill some food?
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/1/question: Does your child get your attention or try to show you something by pulling on your hand or clothes?
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/2/question: Does your child drink from a cup or glass, putting it down again with little spilling?
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/3/question: Does your child copy the activities you do, such as wipe up a spill, sweep, shave, or comb hair?
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/4/question: When playing with either a stuffed animal or a doll, does your child pretend to rock it, feed it, change its diapers, put it to bed, and so forth?
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/5/question: Does your child eat with a fork?
